comments:
I may not have the correct version on my path, but before checking the default
configuration I captured this exception.  Source lookup shouldn't halt because
one archive is missing.  

java.util.zip.ZipException: The system cannot find the path specified
at java.util.zip.ZipFile.open(Native Method)
at java.util.zip.ZipFile.<init>(ZipFile.java:204)
at java.util.zip.ZipFile.<init>(ZipFile.java:85)

Yes, if one "source container" does not exist, source lookup should continue 
to check other containers on the path.

This was a pretty mysterious one for me.  Some time between M6 and M7, I stopped
being able to do source-level debugging -- even though the class and source
paths were completely fine Eclipse would just come up with the default "no
source".  Clearly something is broken somewhere in my configuration (this
configuration is one that has stayed with me through successive milestone
installs), but the fact that M6 _can_ debug and show me source and M7 _cannot_
is definitely of concern.

I will try to test again with M7 and see how it is.

The composite source container handled the problem properly, but the 
AbstractSourceLookupParticipant did not. It bailed if one container on the 
path threw an exception. 

With the change, an exception is only reported if source cannot be found in 
any container, and a single container threw an exception.

Fixed in SourceLookupParticipant.

As the originator I'd like to point out the following:  Something in my M6
configuration directory was causing the problem, for me.  I was able to fix the
problem by creating a fresh install of Eclipse as a _different_ user under
Windows XP.  This caused Eclipse to put certain configuration information into
the "Documents and Settings" private directory for that user.  When I opened up
the a workspace under my main user ID, I could not debug through source.  When I
opened up the exact same workspace as a _different_ user (who had a different
configuration storage location), I _could_ debug through source.  This odd
behavior persisted even when I installed and ran Eclipse completely from scratch
with no existing configuration behavior.

I know this is confusing, but there it is.  Through some combination of running
Eclipse under different user IDs and erasing and regenerating configuration
directories my problem was solved.  My best guess is that there is some kind of
key initialization that happens correctly ONLY when some default workspace
configuration information is chosen.  If that location is not present or is
somewhere else, certain configuration information is not correctly initialized.

But that's a wild-ass guess.
